p: There are two strategies for CMV disease prevention after liver transplantation: preemptive therapy and antiviral prophylaxis [ 56]. For preemptive therapy, CMV reactivation is monitored by sensitive assays; upon detection, antiviral drugs are administered early to halt progression of the asymptomatic infection to full-blown clinical disease [ 67]. Preemptive therapy with oral ganciclovir or intravenous ganciclovir or valganciclovir resulted in reduction of CMV disease by 70 % [ 68], and, unlike antiviral prophylaxis, was not associated with late-onset CMV disease. Valganciclovir is currently the most commonly used drug for preemptive therapy. Preemptive therapy may not be completely effective in CMV D+/Râˆ’ liver transplant recipients because the replication kinetics of CMV in immune deficient individuals is very rapid [ 66].
